review: Do you remember those dumb 2012 prophecy scare tactics shows that the History Channel used to put out in the mid to late 2000s? This is sort of the adventure game equivalent to those, and it’s very mediocre. Originally released in 2007, Nostradamus suffers from similar problems plaguing adventure games at the time, including a few obnoxious timed puzzles and some confusing puzzles that are best solved with a guide unless you want to metaphorically rip your hair out. The storyline is alright, I guess, and the highlight of the game is the protagonist, Madeline, who plays with gender boundaries by disguising herself as her brother through out the plot. It also hasn’t aged well for modern computers and was a little difficult to get running when I played it in 2019.

author: {'steamid': '76561198160203144', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 763, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 763, 'last_played': 1677295761}
review:
It hurts me to give this a thumbs-down because this game was 95% of the way to being wonderful, but it completely face-planted at the ending.

Most of the game is a perfect late 90's/early 2000's adventure game: plenty of puzzles (some logical, some not), awkward dialogue, voice acting ranging from decent to laughably bad, and a needlessly complex plot. If you've made it to the review page, you know the type of game, and you're probably thinking "awesome, this is right up my alley!" And it is, I had a ton of fun playing it until.......

The final puzzle is timed. And it's a multi-part puzzle. And there are no checkpoints. I guess the devs thought it would add excitement? Or they thought the game needed a "final boss"? Whatever the logic, the decision to add a timed puzzle completely ruined my entire experience. Games of this nature live and die with their atmosphere: exploring locations, combing for clues, guessing and checking different solutions. All of this takes time, and these games are fun because you can go at your own pace. Adding a timer adds nothing but frustration as I had to keep loading and re-loading my save to re-do the parts of the puzzle I'd already done, only to fail at the next part and start all over.

I still kind of want to recommend this because it was such an enjoyable game but the ending left such a bad taste in my mouth that I just can't. A real shame.

author: {'steamid': '76561198217689948', 'num_games_owned': 1077, 'num_reviews': 219, 'playtime_forever': 107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 107, 'last_played': 1658763144}
review:
Produkcja się strasznie zestarzała. Mechanicznie to początek XXI wieku - poruszanie się jest "drewniane", mdli podczas gry od 16 klatek na sekundę (tak, to "normalne". Tak ktoś to napisał, że gra działa w tylu klatach, nawet w menu gry), a obracanie się jest jak na mechanicznym ramieniu - kompletnie zero-jedynkowo, jakby gra była złożona z bloków. Mam duży żal do wydawców, że nie postanowili "unowocześnić" jej choć trochę - dodać 60 klatek i wybór opcji w menu (gra takich "udogodnień" nie posiada niestety, a domyślnie odpala się w bardzo niskiej rozdzielczości), usprawnić mechanikę poruszania się, dodać wsparcie dla wysokich rozdzielczości i możliwość przypisania klawiszy klawiatury do konkretnych czynności.

Jednocześnie gra jest okrutna jeśli chodzi o poziom trudności i "skomplikowanie zagadek", co jest typowe dla przygodówek z lat 2000. Typowy przypadek produkcji, gdzie do gry dołączany powinien być od razu poradnik jak ją przejść. Zapewne to bardzo ciekawa historia, bo czuć, że klimat jest ciężki i "w grze o coś chodzi", ale nie da się w nią grać od ilości błędów i archanizmów. Mam nadzieję, że autorzy (albo osoby mające prawa do marki) wykonają jakiś krok ku temu, by gra była bardziej przystępna.

[h1]4/10[/h1]

review:
I've been going back and playing some of the much older games in my collection to complete them - this is one of them, so it's important to review it in the context of the time, rather than against current games.

That said - the puzzles are definitely challenging and while I did use a hints page to get through some of them, they were overall quite achievable.  The story was simple and suited the short game.  

Technically, it was considered on par with the graphics & gameplay of the times (2004) and while there are annoying aspects (such as not being able to skip dialogue), these aren't dealbreakers.  The ability to have multiple saves has always been a winner for me and it's a shame modern games have often removed that option.

Overall, it's a good way to pass a few hours if you're interested in the mythos of Nostrodamus, herbs and stars, or if you just want to dip your toe in the nostalgia of early 2000's gaming.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986657824', 'num_games_owned': 984, 'num_reviews': 229, 'playtime_forever': 652, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 652, 'last_played': 1629063716}
review:
La verdad es que estamos ante un juego bastante mediocre...es un juego que hace aguas en bastantes de sus áreas, como el sistema de inventario, que es muy poco intuitivo y bastante molesto, los gráficos (aunque tenga sus añitos, no creo que tampoco en su tiempo fuera un desmadre), el argumento [spoiler](típico juego en el que todas las pruebas hacen que te encamines a un sospechoso muy obvio para luego de la nada y sin mucha explicación, sacarse otro de la manga)[/spoiler], por no hablar del hecho de que la mitad del juego parece más un simulador de cocina que una aventura (por las recetas que tienes que estar haciendo continuamente).

Lo más llamativo del juego (y no en el buen sentido) es que el juego se llame Nostradamus y perfectamente podría haber sido "tu vecino del quinto", ya que el nombre es una mera excusa (entiendo que para que venda más) y no te pondrás en la piel del famoso adivino, sino de su hija (y encima debes travestirte porque sino en palacio no te harán ni caso)...actuando el primero de mera comparsa, estando prácticamente siempre sentado o tumbado y apenas interactuando contigo más que en algún momento, lo cual no deja de ser curioso.

En cuanto a las dos cosas que suelen atraer al que busca una buena aventura; como digo, el argumento está bastante cogido por los pelos y deja mucho que desear. Y en cuanto a los puzzles, algunos están bien tirados, pero muchos dependen demasiado de simples recetas o incluso alguno de tus conocimientos de francés (sí, así, a pelo)...en resumen, no son muy destacables.

En resumen, juego para olvidar. No lo recomiendo!

author: {'steamid': '76561198022854959', 'num_games_owned': 794, 'num_reviews': 383, 'playtime_forever': 404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 404, 'last_played': 1622991822}
review:
Nostradamus: The Last Prophecy is a fun point-and-click game with an interesting and engaging story. The graphics look outdated but the beautiful artwork and great voice acting definitely make up for it. The atmosphere reminded me a little bit of the old "Myst" games.

There are a good variety of puzzles, some of them simple and some of them more complex. I really liked how they were incorporated in the story. They didn't feel forced and were rather logical. 

The timed puzzles were the only thing I didn't like about this game. I wouldn't have minded one timed puzzle, but there were a series of timed puzzles you had to solve directly after each other. People, who need a little bit more time to figure out how a puzzle works, will most likely not enjoy this part of the game. 

There is also a possibility that your character dies; I recommend saving the game regularly.

review: This is a classic point and click game.  While I was willing to deal with the rigid nature of such games because of the theme of the game, I have to give it a big thumbs down.  The reason is that, about 3/4 of the way through the game, there seems to be a bug which prevents me from making any further progress (I can't get the double arrows to appear on the glyph translation section after discovering the tomb beneath the building). review:
Jeu sympathique, très classique dans la forme qui peut se jouer en quelques heures.

L'ensemble est assez reposant, vous évoluez dans un espace assez réduit (la maison, le château et un peu le village) avec quelques actions du quotidien (faire du pain par exemple), des préparations de potions diverses (si vous cherchez la grande aventure, vous risquez de vous ennuyer, sinon vous apprécierez le rythme plutôt tranquille). Peu de scènes chronométrées ou de chances de mourir durant votre enquête.
Les personnages et les dialogues ne sont pas d'une grande profondeur (et souvent totalement anachroniques ce qui n'aide pas à l'immersion) mais là encore, ça se tient et les énigmes sont assez logiques et s'intègrent plutôt bien dans le scénario. Quelques passages plus ardus mais l'ensemble reste plutôt simple mais néanmoins suffisamment intéressant et agréable à jouer.

Rien d'inoubliable donc mais un bon moment

author: {'steamid': '76561198036328736', 'num_games_owned': 3959, 'num_reviews': 727, 'playtime_forever': 637, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 637, 'last_played': 1591098757}
review:
[b]Sympathique [i]point&click[/i] qui nous invite à résoudre une troublante affaire de meurtres avec l'aide de Nostradamus.[/b]


En 1566, Catherine de Médicis (la mère du Roi) sollicite le célèbre astrologue Nostradamus car depuis quelques jours une personne meurt quotidiennement dans l'entourage de la cour. Une de ses fameuses prophéties semble décrire les événements et prédit qu'après le 12ème décès, la famille royale sera directement touchée. Or le vieil homme n'est plus certain d'être réellement l'auteur de cette prédiction.
Affaibli par sa santé fragile et en l'absence de son fils César, Nostradamus décide de confier la mission d'éclaircir cette affaire à sa fille Madeleine. Mais en lui demandant de se déguiser pour se faire passer pour son frère.


L'éphémère studio Khéops était spécialisé dans les [i]point&click[/i] basés sur un contexte historique réel ou sur une oeuvre littéraire. Après avoir mis en scène l'Egypte antique de Ramsès et Cléopâtre, les travaux de Léonard de Vinci ou les récits de Jules Verne et Robert Louis Stevenson, il proposait en 2007 avec ce jeu une nouvelle aventure évoquant des événements réels du royaume et des croyances liées aux écrits de Nostradamus.



[u][b]J'ai aimé :[/b][/u]
[b]+++ la diversité des activités : [/b]Le gros point fort du jeu est en effet qu'on est amené à faire beaucoup de choses différentes et résoudre des énigmes variés durant notre aventure. Madeleine devra démontrer son talent dans des domaines comme l'astrologie, l'alchimie / herboristerie, le bricolage, la cuisine, les mathématiques, le décryptage, la police scientifique, la diplomatie ou le forgeage.

[b]+++ la difficulté bien dosée : [/b]Le joueur n'est jamais assisté comme dans bien des jeux récents et il lui faut vraiment réfléchir un minimum. Néanmoins le jeu ne comporte jamais rien de complètement illogique ou de réellement bloquant, au pire un simple petit tour auprès de chaque interlocuteur ou un oeil dans le journal de bord permet de vérifier que rien n'a été oublié par mégarde.

[b]++ la double identité : [/b]Le fait qu'on puisse se présenter sous les traits de César ou de Madeleine est pris en compte par le jeu et influe sur le comportement de nos interlocuteurs. Sympa.

[b]+ le gameplay: [/b]Simple et efficace, le gameplay n'a pratiquement aucun défaut même selon les critères d'aujourd'hui. Déplacements sur des emplacements qui offrent une vue à 360°, zones d'action claires, dialogues, inventaire. Mention spéciale au journal regroupant notes, indices, documents, prochains objectifs et dans lequel on est amené à écrire directement pour résoudre certaines énigmes.

[b]+ le scénario : [/b]Sans être absolument extraordinaire, l'histoire connait quelques rebondissements et s'amuse de quelques zones d'ombre de l'Histoire.

[b]+ les graphismes : [/b]Agréables à regarder et à jouer, ils ont particulièrement bien vieillis pour ce genre de jeu.



[u][b]J'ai moins aimé :[/b][/u]
[b]- le scénario : [/b]On pourra lui reprocher d'être excessivement linéaire car les actions possibles, les événements ou les énigmes surviennent toujours dans un ordre pratiquement immuable. Des portes seront par exemple simplement fermées ou ouvertes selon l'intérêt de se rendre ou non ici ou là à tel ou tel moment de l'intrigue.

[b]- le chrono et la mort : [/b]On pourra regretter la présence de quelques phases chronométrées, bien que peu exigeantes, et le fait qu'on puisse connaître la mort dans certaines circonstances, malgré que ce ne soit jamais réellement punitif (retour au début de la séquence).

[b]- l'ergonomie de l'inventaire : [/b]Il comporte curieusement trois onglets qui ne se justifient pas vraiment et qui ne sont pas toujours très pratiques.

[b]- l'univers réduit : [/b]Les lieux visitables se limitent uniquement à la maison familiale, une partie du château et les environs immédiats du village. Les amateurs de voyages et d'exploration seront frustrés mais les lieux existants restent bien exploités. 

[b]- le doublage : [/b]On a certes vu pire mais le doublage reste assez inégal et pas toujours franchement convaincant.



Avec le temps, [i]Nostradamus : La Dernière Prophétie[/i] est devenu un classique du [i]point&click[/i] et un bon représentant du genre des années 2000 même s'il ne possède ni la poésie de [i]Syberia[/i], l'ambiance de [i]Black Mirror[/i], l'humour de [i]The Westerrner[/i], l'originalité du concept de [i]Experience 112[/i] ou la profondeur des thèmes traités dans [i]Overclocked[/i] ou [i]The Moment of Silence[/i]. Ca reste néanmoins un bon divertissement où la diversité des activités prime toutefois sur la difficulté ou la qualité du scénario.

A recommander à tous les amateurs de [i]point&click[/i] qui savent s'accommoder avec les caractéristiques des jeux peu récents et qui n'ont pas besoin d'être exagérément pris par la main.

Les fans de casse-têtes trouveront probablement que les énigmes manquent de difficulté et qu'ils sont plus souvent ralentis par un clic oublié ici ou là plutôt que par un défi intellectuel impressionnant.


Je recommande.

review:
Absolutely everything I wanted and needed from a first-person game.  Great story, an amazing immersive experience.  The ending sequence was so fast, but I've seen way worse.  It was so difficult at times but exactly the difficulty that keeps you interested (save OFTEN).  There are games that you need to literally quit because the difficulty is way too hard.

Very few things bothered me from gameplay.  Being able to see a ladder but not be able to pick it up (because using a rope to climb is so much better) lol.

I was mesmerized with the astrological content, since I am a novice "astrologer".  Felt very comfortable solving those puzzles.  The hardest one was the planets with the weights you needed to balance (what a pain), nothing to do with astrology, more towards the astronomy/science side.

Overall, a game that inspires me to re-play at least once more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048924830', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 143, 'playtime_forever': 20, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1516335217}
review:
je ......  ne peut pas me retenir de poster l'évaluation maintenant , tellement  ça ma fais rager et rire en meme temp..


le jeu en lui meme est une petite perle, tres simpa.
graphiquement plaisant, c'est pas du top, mais ça reste bien beau et simpa.
un point and clic, donc on se deplace de piece en piece grace au clic. mais ! ... on a une vue subjective premiere personne qui nous donne une immersion bien simpa. ajouter a cela le fais que pour regarder autour on bouge la souris simplement, ça nous donne une petite impression dans le style d'un VR. tres agreable.
en déplaçant la vue on déplace évidement le curseur de la souris qui va nous servir a attraper les objets, les activer etc..
le jeu dispose d'un inventaire bien fait ( je trouve ) afin de voir notre gros bordel que l'on a dans nos poches sans fond, le trier, le jeter, etc... ( on peut meme changer de vetements, et c'est vraiment utile, pas juste la pour faire beau)

ben alors ? vous allez me dire... ou est le probleme ? parce que la, je ne voi rien de drole ou d'énervant..

ok, nous y voila... dans le jeu, il y a 2 points qui sont a la fois simpa et chiant ( a l'extreme)

1er point
vous n'avez absolument aucune aide direct, en gros, aucun ATH, aucun indice, juste quelques infos via l'inventaire. pour le reste "plan B".
mission : trouver un moyen d'assombrir votre teint ( ne chercher pas, c'est une véritable mission dans le jeu , me demandez pas le pourquoi du comment ).  pour ça, il va vous falloir trouver une recette ( ça déja, on ne vous la absolument pas indiquer, il faut donc le deviner ) , ensuite, une fois la recette trouver, il faut trouver les ingrédient... puis les préparez etc..  bref, vous avez compris.. sans la moindre aide, on tourne en rond pendant des heures sans vraiment savoir ce que l'on cherche.

2e point
les actions.. dans un but de réalisme, d'absurdité, ou simplement pour emmerder le joueur. les devs se sont dit qu'ils serait simpa d'implenter dans le jeu quelques actions réaliste ( et totalement absurde, si ce n'est pour troller ) .
revenont a notre mission précedente... nous avons nos ingredients pour notre pate/pommade pour assombrir notre peau...
je me dirige donc vers la table de préparation. je lis attentivement la recette, je verse les doses etc.. dans la marmitte. impec', me reste plus qu'a chauffer le tout et c'est bientot fini ( enfin, je tourne en rond depuis 4 heures pour trouver ses foutus ingrédients ).
je prend ma marmitte a deux mains, je me tourne vers le feu....................................... et dans une action, on ne peut plus stupide, implenter dans le jeu par les devs ( merci... vraiment.. -_- ) . mon personnage trouve tres intelligent de vider totallement la marmitte sur le feu.
NON DIDIOU !!!

s'en suit une réaction en chaine qui ma franchement fait rager comme aucun jeu ne m'avai fait rager depuis des années...

non seulement la totalité du contenu de la marmitte vient de disparaitre dans le feu ( et donc, c'est foutu, c'est mort, kapoute... ) , il apparait que la marmitte ne se rempli pas comme par magie.... oui... vous avez compris ? ... il me faut donc a nouveau recommencer toute la recette a zero. -_-
et pour combler le tout, genre comme si ça suffisait pas... par une logique naturelle , en versant le contenu de la marmitte sur le feu, ce dernier c'est fait éteindre . il faudra donc au passage rallumer le feu de nouveau.


alors, je vous vois venir... vous allez dire : " bah c'est facile , tu recommence la recette ça prend 20 secondes et basta. "

oui, c'est vrai... mais c'est surtout le fait que j'ai perdu des heures a chercher ce qu'il fallait faire avant de découvrir la fameuse recette et en arriver la... tout ça pour voir le resultat dont j'était franchement rassurer de terminer etre réduit a néant en 2 secondes a cause d'une logique stupide de permettre au personnage de vider une marmitte dans le feu  -_-
( je rappel que vous n'avez absolument AUCUNE indication de ce que vous devez faire... imaginez donc ma réaction )

et, comme vous l'aurez compris... il ne s'agit la que d'UNE SEULE mission du jeu... toute semble etre du meme accabit. je m'attend donc a franchement rager a cause d'un mauvais clic a tout moment.


mis a part ces 2 gros défauts... il faut noter quelque chose d'important, c'est que le jeu est aussi 100% français, texte et voix, que les voix françaises sont franchement bien faites. voila qui redonne un peu de bon a ce jeu, qui dans l'ensemble se montre bien simpa. j'aurai juste aimer qu'il n'y ai pas ce systeme de clic absurde pour des actions qui le sont encore plus.


7,5/10  ( il les mérite je trouve )

+ le coté immersion style VR
+ les doublages 100% français
+ l'histoire
+ l'utilisation de la souris pour observer et agir
+ les graphisme vraiment bon
+ tout en 3D temp réel

- le manque d'indications totale
- les interactions/actions totalement stupides réalisable d'un simple mauvais clic



PS: je vais le finir pour sur, il est captivant

author: {'steamid': '76561198023019965', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 499, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 493, 'last_played': 1498424940}
review:
Nostradamus: The Last Prophecy was made by a group of french developers who were related to Cryo the company that created Atlantis The lost Tales in 1997. This game was made in 2007 ~ so it was a welcome back to some great puzzles and game things that were missing at that time. The game doesn't have high production values and that shows especially today after 10 years, but still what keeps my interest in this game now and kept it long time ago when i played it for the first time was the game mechanics. This game has a story of course (it is not only puzzles) there are many dialogs and there is story development to be found, suspense and murder along the way, but the main thing about this game was its puzzles (most of them, not all) wich are, interestingly @fun@ (who would knew!) something that other adventure games lack some times (many times).
Of course, that depends largely on what you consider fun as a puzzle, but if you are interested in playing as madeleine, daughter of nostradamus, in the XVI century france, making potions , food and weird concotions at the laboratory and then drawing astrological charts, writing predictions based on natal charts and looking at constellations to find hidden clues to a murder(s) then i think you will like it. The game, as a said, gives you in several parts of the game receipts to prepare all sorts of things ranging from making bread (!) preapring tea, to preparing aphrodisiac and then making a mold key or even make up. All is fun and well done and you have many of the ingredients in you lab, but some of them you will have to go and look for them.  In other parts of the game you go to Nostradamus observatory and look to the stars or use one of his contraptions to make predictions and birth charts. Some of them are intuitive and some of them are not (there are a few obscure puzzles there) but you always have the option to use a walkthrough if you are stuck) The game has many environmental and action puzzles, meaning doing things related to a scene. Of course you investigate crime scene(s) and you have your hour glass thingy, and you scalpel, and tweezer and all the renaissance detectives tools you could wish for (and you will use them, each one of them)
The third and most interesting thing about this game was the role played by madeleine (the main character in this game)
She is a woman from the XVI century and as such she is not given the same allowance to do things as his brother, cesar, so, when a murder is comitted in the royal court and nostradamus is called to investigate but he is not able to go because of his deteriorating health, he sends his daughter dress as man (madeleine's brother) so as to allow her to investigate and do all necesary things to solve the mistery. And far from being a gender thing (wich it is of course) the character uses her disguise as a man to investigate and meet some characters, but also changes to be dressed as a woman (as herlself) to take advantage of that in certain situations. So, instead of taking a solemn approach and making it a gender thing only, and showing up as a victim herself, on the contrary the main character, madeleine, plays around its limitations that society puts on her because of being a woman in the XVI century and instead she takes advantage of that and plays around it and takes advantage of all the characters around her, as a woman and as a man, making it a true androgynous character, wich is refreshing in a way, and also takes courage to do so in a game. But, anyway, thats not the main point of the game (allthough you are crossdressing from beginning to almost the end, when you cover is off) but the main story is the murder of someone in the court of the queen wich is related to an old prophecy nostradamus wrote , and off you go to investigate that and work with nostradamus across several days.

The end of the story, its a little rushed and could have been a little more developed, but it serves the story right and all is completed, one way or the other. The expression of all the characters in this game, its a little lacking...especially for that few moments where important things happens, but again, its a game from 2007, and a low budget one at that, so you can't ask for a fully developed graphical experience here. What you will get instead its a game full of things to do, obects and ingredients to get , many potions to prepare, a lot of crossdressing to take advantage of and a good amount of astrological drawings and birth charts to make along the way.

review:
Nostradamus: The Last Prophecy is a length point-and-click game that ultimately disappoints. 

Pros:
- Voice acting throughout. I appreciate games that do that. I don't want to be reading the entire time!
- Long length. I like to see any game in this genre that is longer than 5 hours. I want my money's worth.

Cons:
- Sometimes the subtitles at the bottom of the screen didn't match what the character was speaking. That bothers me.
- There wasn't any kind of tutorial in the beginning to explain how the game mechanics work. The inventory system and the tools on the side of the screen (scissors, scalpel, etc) are more complicated than they seem.
- No achievements! Lame.
- Some of the puzzles in this game were way too cryptic or ambiguous. There is no way I would be able to finish this game without a walkthrough. For example, there is a moment in the game where you need the key to a locked door, and you are able to make an imprint of the key shape when a certain character isn't looking. You are only able to do this when you are speaking to that character though. If I recall correctly, that is the only point in the game where something is interactable while a conversation is going on. 
- Maybe I wasn't pressing the right buttons, but the dialogue wasn't skippable! One of the most annoying things a game can do. I don't want to sit through the same lines multiple times.
- The whole last section of the game was terrible. There is a time limit to finding the solutions. A time limit to finding the solutions to an already diffficult game! What an awful idea. Also, the ending to the game was extremely lackluster.

I didn't have high expectations going into this game, and I'm glad I didn't. I was very disappointed in how the game played out, and I don't think I can recommend this game to anyone who doesn't have loads of free time on their hands. 

There were no jump scares exactly, but sometimes you turn the corner or into a new room and someone is just standing there staring at you. That could get a little unsettling.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025152136', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 418, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 418, 'last_played': 1479773289}
review:
I have a fondness for puzzle games and this game caught my attention, so I bought it as soon as I could. Overall, this game is quite impressive.

I really enjoyed the storyline and how it unfolded so eloquently; it's quite the crime story. The music added great atmosphere and didn't interfere with the voice-over, SFX, or the gameplay itself. The aesthetic of the game was spot on and the game itself designed to allow quite a bit of freedom to wander around; I wanted to explore every nook and cranny of the map to see what I can find and what I can interact with.

It does have a few shortcomings though. The voice actors didn't really convince me of anything; it actually sounded like they were reading their script. The characters themselves are very stiff; there wans't enough animation done to allow body language so at times it seemed as though you were interacting with a cardboard cutout. The game is also rather short, and it feels short; I would have liked it to be a bit longer with a few more puzzles.

With all that said, I would recommend this game to anyone wanting to play something a bit different.

review:
Originální point&click adventura, kterou ale táhne dolů řada nedotažeností.
Zpracováním jde o hru s pohledem první osoby, kde se ale nepohybujete volně, ale přecházíte mezi připravenými pozicemi podobně jako v Google Street View nebo ve hrách Nikopol a Darkness Within. Zpracování je povedené a možnost volného rozhlížení přidává na atmosféře. Příběh tvoří poměrně zajímavá detektivka, herní úkoly jsou rozmanité a musím pochválit nápaditě navržené minihry a hlavolamy. Zajímavé je i řešení problémů více způsoby v závislosti na zrovna používaném převleku.
Problémů je několik. Hra nijak neoznačuje aktivní zóny a je snadné přehlédnout miniaturní, ale nezbytně nutný předmět. Interakce s aktivními zónami neposkytuje žádnou zpětnou vazbu; žádný popis, komentáře k nesprávnému použití, nic. To způsobuje řadu zbytečných zákysů, když se pokusíte řešit problém jinak než autoři zamýšleli. Například prášek do hrnce nemůžete nasypat, ale musíte ho nabrat lžičkou, což ale hra nijak nenaznačí.
Hra také obsahuje velmi nestandardní inventář se spoustou funkcí. O těch se ale opět nic nedozvíte a musíte je buď objevit sami nebo se o nich dočíst v návodu.

review:
Usually, I don't even touch point and click adventures, but I wanted to give this game a try becuase of the setting and the story being about Nostradamus. 

Puzzles, mystery, beautiful art, I got hooked! I really liked the twist at the start that involves cross-dressing. Some choices in the game lead to a different way the story plays out even though the main storyline is linear. I really enjoyed the cooking and potion making as well as the challenging puzzles! The music was pensive at times, but enjoyable and fit with the flow of the story. If you like collecting clues to add to your journal and inventory while investigating a mystery, then chances are you will enjoy this game!

Criticisms...

Although I don't regret even one minute I spent with this game, I wish there was a bit more lore at the end about the story behind what happened and a resolution for those who were involved.

Also, the game ends with "%d points" - there is a point counter in game for things you do correctly, but you can't see them when the credits roll.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964863427', 'num_games_owned': 1547, 'num_reviews': 192, 'playtime_forever': 497, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 497, 'last_played': 1456970124}
review:
The game starts nicely enough, and I must commend the artists who have done an excellent job. The renaissance Italy, full of colors and rich in details, provides an excellent and atmospheric setting for the upcoming adventure. Nostradamus, horoscopes (strangely called "charts" in the game), historical figures, sinister plot threatening the ruling family, all that is very promising and fresh. You can even pose as man or woman according to your wish, and the dialogues play slightly differently, which I found impressive.

However, as the game unveils, its quality starts to deteriorate. The translation is not very good, sometimes you wrestle with an odd expression of unclear meaning. There is absolutely minimal amount if animation in the game - a guard extends his arm, woman throws dice, Nostradamus nods and smiles. At one occasion, you talk to a person over a closed door, which no doubt saved the dev team some time and effort.  The late game puzzles become infuriating, especially a particular substitution cipher where you must decipher.. a French text, probably because translating the cipher would take too much effort. The characters are barely legible and sometimes similar, for example the character "-" (hyphen) means three different letters. 

The game also suffers from a split personality disorder. One moment you discover a dead body in a room, and are getting ready to open his personal chest to shed light on his murder, but your character refuses - Nah, probably nothing in there. Just another corpse. Without reporting your find, you are suddenly teleported to your home. Nostradamus listens to your  report about the murder and then gives you a very important task - to brew a herbal tea, so that you can sleep better. I run back to the castle in the middle of the night, but the drawbridge was closed. Nobody cares. Another dead body? Old news.

The game ends, I imagine, in a moment when the dev team run out of finances, their creditors probably stormed their offices, and started confiscating computer equipment. A duo of artists in the back room decided to quickly conclude the game with a 20 seconds long cutscene that makes absolutely no sense whatsoever, and that's it, end of story. 

"You have finished the game with %d points".

"%d" is a symbol for numeric value in formatted print. The programmer was probably dragged away by then, so there was nobody to correct the error. 

What a pity.

review:
Das Spiel war bei mir im großen Microids enthalten. Vorweg: Ich bin ohne große Erwartungen herangangen. 

Grafik: 6,5/10 (25%)
- Für ein älteres Game ansehnliche Grafik durch vorgerenderte "360°-Rundum-Stand-Sicht". Ähnlich wie bei Myst mit vorgerenderten Inhalten.
- Fortbewegung mittels Klick durch die einzelnen Szenen -> Durch das Vorrendering auch heute noch schön anzusehen
- Charaktere wirken wie bei den meisten Adventures leider eher holzig

Sound: 5/10 (10%)
- Keine besondere musikalische Untermalung
- Eher passable Fahrstuhlmusik
- Synchro ist ok, mehr auch nicht

Story/Atmosphäre: 5/10 (50%)
- Der Plot ist an sich nicht sehr orginell. -> Es geschehen seltsame Todesfälle im Hause de Medici. Nostradamus unser Vater hatte vor Jahren eine Vorhersage dazu getätigt und die Königin ersucht diesen nun um Rat. Da unser Vater dem älteren Semester angehört, schickt er seine Tocher in der Verkleidung seines Sohnes zur Königin um das Rätsel der Tode zu ergründen. Bei den bisherigen Toten bleibt es nicht und die Geschichte spitzt sich zu. So oder so ähnlich dachten sich die Autoren das wahrscheinlich. Leider hält sich die Emotionalität wie auch die Verbundenheit zu den Charakteren eher in Grenzen, ähnlich wie bei einem GrimTales-Abenteuer.
- Die Szenerie der Toskana in der Renaissance wird glaubhaft vermittelt. Es hätten aber ruhig ein paar mehr Bewohner zumindest im Hintergrund als Statisten mitwirken können. Das Anwesen wirkt ob seiner Größe recht leer.  

Rätsel: 7/10 (15%)
- Die Rätseleinlagen waren meist logisch und motivierend. Astologiekenntnisse sind hier nicht verkehrt :) 
- Positiv sind die kleinen Alchemieeinlagen hängengeblieben, bei denen wir uns Tränke und Mixturen herstellen konnten oder auch mal die Schmide und den Ofen interaktiv benutzen durften

Spielzeit: Ca. 10h
Spielewertung: 5,5/10
Genrewertung: 7/10
Empfehlung: Für Adventure-Liebhaber, die sich gerne auf ein (leicht) überdurchschnittliches Genreerlebnis einlassen möchten.

review:
Nostradamus is a point & click adventure where you (or at least your brother) are recruited to investigate a curse that is unfolding based on a quatrain written by Nostradamus himself. Nostradamus, your father, is in his late years now: old, weak, and frail. Since your brother is away, and because of the time period a woman does not seem fit to handle the task, your father sees it best to disguise you as your brother to help the queen's mother solve the mystery of people close to her dying as she is now in fear of her own life.

Being a Microids game, the gameplay is quite good with a lot of similarities to Syberia and Return to Mysterious Island. It involves a lot of detective work with very engaging puzzles. The game also provides a good foundation of early astrology and chemistry. Highly enjoyable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068817861', 'num_games_owned': 356, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 543, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 543, 'last_played': 1451946548}
review:
Recently, I've been on a point-and-click spree. While most games disappointed, Nostradamus: The Last Prophecy actually won me over, and over, and over again. 

What is so good about this game?
First of all, it's the graphics - they are old, sure. But they are accordingly old. It's not like you're supposedly playing a game set in 2044 while it looks like it's actually 1999. Then, you have an immersive OST and a lovely background music choice in most locations.

The puzzles are something that I would like to compliment extensively. You have puzzles that are actually involved in the story line. This, you won't see often even in puzzle-based quests. They are different; you cannot solve two in the same way or even with the same type of analogy. You have different types of puzzles: from reflectory to balancing to runes. On top of this, they really do seem important. 

Something else I love about it is that they never really killed the good old guy, although many characters did meet their end. 

I particularly enjoyed the cross-dressing part. A nice twist on the old gender definitions. And yet, even this was realised through puzzles. You need to arrange voice manneurisms in order to achieve complete consistency. 

If anyone is wondering if they want to try this game, I wholeheartedly recommend it to them. If you think the puzzles are too hard, it just means you need more experience - they are one of the most pleasurable parts of point-and-click adventure games.

review:
Pretty cool game with nice unique features involving disguise and decoding of astrological riddles.
To be fair most of the negative reviews here have to do with technical issues and not the game itself. I ran in on Windows 10 and it worked perfectly.
The game has a rather unique atmosphere and nice voice acting, visuals and music. It's for fans of the genre - not for someone who want a straightforward and popular game. Even though the game involves murder mystery it has a nice and almost cozy atmosphere most of the time. Unlike some point and click adventures it's actually possible to take a few different roads at certain times. Not something that changes the story dramatically, but it adds a nice flavour.
It took me 7 hours to complete and I think I was neither slow nor fast. I guess fast players could complete it in 5 hours while other players would get stuck forever.
Some of the puzzles are really innovative and a few are almost impossible (e.g. the very last prophecy puzzzle). I actually needed paper and a pencil to solve some of the puzzles which I think is good. You have to really think to complete this game. Definitely recommended for fans of the genre and not for the typical gamer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061249750', 'num_games_owned': 1173, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 93, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 93, 'last_played': 1442451715}
review:
For me, a good point and click lives and dies on two things: plot and immersion. Myst, for all it's strange and convoluted puzzles, was utterly engrossing, and still is. Conversely, point and clicks made by Telltale and Wadjet Eye are always worth it for their plot and characters, making use of the formula to deliver narrative heavy experiences with some fun puzzles interspersed in between. Even more occasionally, the puzzles can be the main draw with the plot and immersion mixed in perfectly, a la Monkey Island and the majority of LucasArts' work.

Nostadamus has none of these things to keep it interesting. Graphically, it's pretty but uninspired, indistinguishable from any other ye old setting in an attempt to be grounded in realism. The plot is mind-numbingly contrived, going right past charming to a dead serious boredom. Cross dressing is an important concept fascinatingly enough, and is even a key feature listed on the store page. The idea is that as the daughter of the titular character (You don't play as Nostradamus by the way), you're supposed to disguise yourself as your own brother because reasons so you can help Queen Elizabeth solve a curse. I think. There's not much reason for it, outside of the obtuse patriarchal aspect of the olden days, further rendered moot by the fact you're helping a queen and not a king, but whatever. 

The puzzles are mundane, but nothing ever had me stumped for too long up to where I stopped. Often times, the solution was obvious,  but finding the right item to finish it is often hidden in plain sight. Washing my main character's face took far more effort than it should've though, believe me.

It's not that NTLP is a bad game. I've played worse, much worse. However, where some games can still have something redeeming about it in some odd aspect, even ironically, The Lost Prophecy is just unabashedly boring, with little to keep one engaged. As an over all experience, there are far better things to spend time on than an excersize in mediocrity. 

Worth it if you want to cross-dress as a famous prophet's semi-fictional daughter.

review: Nostradamus, non è un gioco molto  conosciuto dalla massa, ma  se amate il genere  avventura vale la pena averlo  in libreria e giocarlo, vi spiegherò  il perchè.  Per  prima cosa, vi troverete  ad impersonare la figlia del  grande  scrittore, una bella ragazza,  personalmente  come donna  mi è piaciuto  vestire i suoi panni,  perchè  si dimostra una persona dolce ma nello stesso tempo riflessiva ;  non c'è spazio  per la noia  perchè  imparerete  a fare  un sacco di cose ,tipo :  impastare il pane, preparare marmellate ,forgiare , raccogliere erbe  e preparare pozioni  con tanto  di ricetta da seguire ...... tranquilli  , trovrete  anche il tempo  per  indagare su  un caso di omicidio  ,e perchè no  pure una partitina a dadi  con una  dama furbetta .Ben riprodotto il castello dove l'arredamento è curato nei minini particolari,dai quadri all'arredamento del'epoca . Un punto  a suo favore  sono sicuramente  i paesaggi, hanno un che  di acquarello, rimarrete  sedotti  da quelle nuvole che offrono  uno spettacolo  insolito  con dei colori  che le giornate  di sole non mostrano, gli  enigmi  sono  ben introdotti nella trama  alcuni  semplici altri  più complessi,ma mai banali  .  Infine  lasciatevi  trasportare dalla trama  e  certamente  vi godrete  questa bella avventura .

review:
Decent game, decent graphics, decent music (though the obvious modern instruments took away from the 1566 feel).

You control Madeleine, on mission from her father Nostradamus to assist the queen with solving murders happening among her people. 

Some serious bullshittery puzzles are mixed in with fun and good ones. The puzzles itself not being hard, but the solving extremely clunky. There is no reset button on puzzles and the game has no checkpoints so there's the possibility of having to restart the game entirely when stuck on a puzzle. Always save before puzzles to make life easier. And use guide on the harder looking ones unless you're masochistic. One missclick and you could be stuck. I ragequit the game ones and decided to use guide through the worst puzzles this time and my life is much better now.

I encountered only one bug where my character was stuck while using items and I had to alt-f4 the game because I could not even open the menu to exit from there.

Outside of the few bullshit puzzles and the one bug I really enjoyed the game. I liked the story, the feeling of the era it was set it, and the chance of using my runology knowledge for something.

Buy on heavy sale, keep a guide open for the puzzles and save often. Then it's an enjoyable game.

review:
[h1]Сюжет:[/h1]
 Нам показывают сценку, в которой к престарелому Нострадамусу приходит королева и сообщает, что одно из его предсказаний начинает сбываться... Начали умирать люди из королевского окружения и в конце смерть может прийти и за самой королевой... Но Нострадамус стал слишком уж забывчивым маразматиком и не только не помнит своего предсказания, но и отказывается сам помогать королеве... Он предлагает ей помощь от своего сына. Королева соглашается. И тут мы встречаемся с главной героиней нашей истории, которая узнает о том, что ей придётся раскрыть тайну смертей на королевском дворе и самое главное перевоплотиться в своего брата... Так и начинается эта увлекательная истории со сложными загадками и духом того самого времени.

[h1]Описание геймплея:[/h1]
 Квест от первого лица в котором перемещаясь из локации в локацию мы можем осматривать только территорию в пределах поворота мыши, при этом шевелиться в рамках данной комнаты нельзя. У нас есть рюкзак в котором мы храним и используем найденные предметы, есть возможность одеть нашего персонажа, есть блокнот в котором пишутся все диалоги из игры, а также всякие интересности типо щипцов, лупы и циркуля и все, это нам пригодиться по ходу игры. В целом эта основа игры во много идет под копирку со многих игр от Kheops Studio (например Return to Mysterious Island 1-2 части).

[h1]Плюсы:[/h1]
¥ Интересные загадки. Астрономическая загадка с составлением гороскопа заслуживает отдельных аплодисментов.
¥ Шикарная русская озвучка.
¥ Красивые декорации, которые погружают нас в 16 век.

[h1]Минусы:[/h1]
¥ Главный минус игре который подпортит ей очень сильно оценку, это то, что игра при запуске дергалась и играть в нее было невозможно. С помощью форумов удалось выяснить, что проблема касается очень многих владельцев Windows 7 и лечится лишь только изменением режима игры на оконный через внутренние файлы игры... А в оконном режиме игра потеряла всю свою атмосферу... Раз уж разработчики выпустили продукт в стиме, могли и предусмотреть, что продукт должен запускаться на новых ОС.

[h1]Итог:[/h1]
В минусах вообщем-то все написал. Если у вас более старая ОС чем Windows 7 - рекомендую.  Или же вам скорее всего придется мириться с оконным режимом игры. Скажу честно, я много потерял проходя ее в таком виде. Оттого не рекомендую эту хорошую игру, т.к. и вы можете столкнуться с такой проблемой.

[h1]Оценка: 5/10[/h1]

[h1]Послесловие:[/h1]
Если вам понравился этот обзор добро пожаловать в группу
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/uojer - тут вы сможете увидеть рекомендованные мною игры, другие обзоры, а также просто пообщаться в хорошей компании.

review:
This was an enjoyable game for me personally, simply because of the puzzles.  If you are not an Astrology buff, you'll have to brush up on your zodiac (as I did), but there are also codes of sorts, where you will have to do some translating. 

I enjoyed the storyline (who doesn't love a good mystery?).  The game is totally on rails, and there are only a handful of active characters and places that you can enter.  Voice acting was done pretty well, although the background music can grate your nerves if you get stuck on something.   There were several days that I had to quit for the night and revisit later when I could think more clearly, and even so I visited a guide once when I became very stuck.

All in all, this was a well-written story/game.

Edit: Perhaps the most important thing to mention was that I got this game in a bundle, and recommend waiting for it to go on a similar sale, as it can be mildly infuriating at times.  It's less so if you didn't pay much for it ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198034113138', 'num_games_owned': 687, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 214, 'last_played': 1416271401}
review:
An absolute gem of a find. Though many may be turned away by the chunky graphics, this is a game that has really captured the true experience of a well made and thoughtful point-and-click adventure game. The voice acting is well done, the graphics (though blocky) are still pleasing to the eye, and the storyline is top notch.

The puzzles range from simple recipies to weight distribution to complex translation of old celtic to french. Though you may find yourself doing many crafting puzzles, they are balanced thoughout the game and not used as a crutch, but as a way of transitioning the player from one objective to the next. 

The only issue I had with the game was that several timed puzzles and one particular quick-time event left me frustrated. It is important to save and save often. 

Other than that, this game was one of the most thought provoking and inviting point-and-click games I have ever played. Being a history buff, I would love to see more games like this, perhaps with characters from William Shakespeare plays. I would recommend anyone who wants a true adventuring experience like Myst to check this out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062269122', 'num_games_owned': 1154, 'num_reviews': 290, 'playtime_forever': 528, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 528, 'last_played': 1410762442}
review:
Creo que podemos fundar un subgénero de aventuras gráficas franchutes en primera persona en las que te mueves haciendo clic en la dirección en la que quieres ir, tipo "Myst", y en las que algunos de los puzzles son, sencillamente, encontrar todas las cosas que vienen en una lista o receta. Llamaré a este género "Aventure du merde", y en general son las aventuras chorras donde vamos a parar a los dos clichés arriba comentados. "Nostradamus: The Last Prophecy" es un ejemplo impecable de una "aventure du merde" donde encarnamos a la hija de Nostradamus, fíjate tú. Nostradamus se pasa la aventura como un maganto profesional: o sentado en su butaca o tumbado en la cama. Por su parte, la hija tendrá que investigar porqué algunos párrafos manuscritos de su padre ocurren en la vida real y qué coj... ocurre.
El caso es que es una aventura muy tonta y no muy complicada. Dudo que cale hondo en alguno de vosotros y no esperéis mucha diversión, pues gran parte del juego es, agárrate el camal, cocinando. ¿Emocionante? No, ¿verdad? Pues por eso, porque es una "aventure du merde".

[b]Como siempre, te pasas tres pueblos. "Myst" es un juegazo, y éste quizá no esté tan mal.[/b] A ver, ignorante de la vida, "Myst" tuvo su gracia pero está sobrevalorado en exceso. Su único atractivo fue la novedad de la época. Está comprobado científicamente por el Departamento de Juegos Sobrevalorados de la Universidad Complutense de Melmac.
[b]¿Para disfrutar el juego hay que aguantar toda la magufada de que Nostradamus predice el futuro y el rollo éste?[/b] No. De hecho, la única manera de disfrutar con el juego es obligando a tu peor enemigo a jugarlo de principio a fin sin pausas para vomitar, pero no quiero dar ideas...
[b]A ver, aver, a ver... ¿Cómo que Nostradamus apenas aparece? Si es quien sale en el logo del juego.[/b] ¿No me has leído antes? Nostradamus se pasa todo el juego como un gadul medalla de oro: tumbado o sentado, e incluso parte del juego es cocinar para él... Que no. No es una broma. Es tan malo como estás pensando. O peor.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032309978', 'num_games_owned': 340, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 602, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 602, 'last_played': 1408047773}
review:
Luckily I got this game on the cheap.

While the game itself is OK, the puzzlesolving mechanics are really terrible. I dont think I've ever been so aggrevated while playing a game. Repeatedly you'll find yourself solving puzzles you really have no way of solving, or so you think. Turns out, for the most part, you'll have to flip between the pages of your in-game diary, or jott down symbols that you have seen on a wall or similar places. 
If they would have made this game so that once you know the basics of the solution so does your character, then this game would have been more enjoyable. As it stands now, it really is'nt.
Also the dialog can't be skipped. This turns really irritating when you have to play certain parts again, or if you happen to click on the wrong dialog option by mistake. This was especially annoying when I at one point had limited time to solve a puzzle, but I obviously had more than enough time to listen to a bunch of rather meaningless dialog. 
There were a few bugs I experienced, one of which almost made me quit playing, but nothing really gamestopping.

If you're an experienced "point'n clicker" and one of the most patient humans alive, you might enjoy the story however. The puzzles were also good (if the mechanics had been better, that is) and quite original. Once you had solved them, and after you stopped crying and trying to scratch your eyes out, you really get a sense of achievement. Because it's really not an easy game.
The voice acting was so-so, the graphics are OK and the music is... present.

I don't think I could have finished this one without a good walkthrough though. So if you plan on playing this game I suggest you find one online.
I also suggest that you make sure noone can hear your screams of rage...

My last tip, for those of you brave enough to venture forth, would be; read your diary. Then read it again, and again, and again... and again. Are you still here? Hello?

author: {'steamid': '76561198044606103', 'num_games_owned': 1275, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 444, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 444, 'last_played': 1406390026}
review:
Les point'n click sont vraiment un genre de jeu particulier. Dans Nostradamus : La Dernière Prophétie le gameplay reste classique : vous jouez une jeune fille, Madeleine, au 16e siècle et vous allez résoudre un mystère terrible grâce à des puzzles, des recettes de confiture et autres joyeusetés. Les aller-retours sont nombreux vu qu'il n'y a que trois zones : la maison de Madeleine et de Nostradamus, le village (minuscule mais utile) et le château. Clairement, le but de ce jeu est que vous soyez pris par son scénario et son ambiance, comme la majorité des point'n click. Celui-ci est d'ailleurs plutôt réussi : les personnages que vous allez croiser sont charismatiques bien que les dialogues ne soient pas très profonds. Il y a quelques retournements de situation relativement étonnants même si, j'avoue, ce n'est rien d'exceptionnel. L'histoire finit tout de même par convaincre et l'ambiance se fait de plus en plus pesante vers la fin du jeu. Bref, on s'y croirait.

Quant aux énigmes, qu'on redoute souvent dans ce genre de jeu, elles sont vraiment accessibles. Rien de bien compliqué si vous vous concentrez un peu. Il y a pas mal d'objets à trouver mais, incroyable, ils ont tous une utilité bien précise, donc évitez d'utiliser la fonction "jeter l'objet" à tout va. J'espère sinon que vous aimez la cuisine, car Madeleine va passer son temps à faire des potions en tout genre. Entre confiture, pain, crême, tysane, on pourrait confondre Nostradamus : La Dernière Prophétie comme un cooking simulator. Je rigole. C'est plutôt des phases sympathiques et les ingrédients ne sont pas si compliqués à trouver (le village servira qu'à choper des plantes en gros). J'ai un peu moins apprécié les scènes "d'action" que je HAIS dans les point'n click car PAS DU TOUT FAITS POUR CA. Genre, aller rapidement à un endroit pour éviter de se faire tuer, avoir une limite de temps dans une énigme... Heureusement ça n'arrive que deux fois dans le jeu, même si c'est juste méga stressant. Pas besoin de sauvegarder tout le temps sinon, il n'y a pas de piège. Autre point, une partie du gameplay est assez peu utilisé (et c'est bien dommage) mais pourtant super amusant : le choix dans les dialogues. En effet, notre papa (Nostradamus) nous explique au tout début du jeu qu'en fonction de ce qu'on dit on se mettra dans la poche ou non la personne avec qui on discute. Et au final... ça sert juste QU'UNE SEULE FOIS et TOUT A LA FIN. SUPER UTILE. Alors que c'était vraiment le plus exploitable quoi.

Ce jeu est quand même une belle expérience car les graphismes sont pas mauvais du tout (le jeu est sorti en 2007, je le rappelle) même si le fait que la résolution soit bloquée à 1024x768 soit assez relou. Les persos ne sont pas très bien animés mais les décors sont très jolis (mais pas très variés). Enfin, de toute façon c'est pour l'histoire que vous y jouerez et éventuellement les résolutions d'énigme, presque toutes basées d'ailleurs sur le thème de l'astrologie. Donc si vous n'aimez pas ça (genre vraiment), n'essayez même pas car le jeu commence direct avec.

Enfin, chose rare je pense dans les point'n click, vous avez un score qui augmente ou qui baisse en fonction de ce que vous faites. Et il ne sert absolument à rien à part vous rendre le zizi tout dur quand vous direz à votre meilleur copain "hé j'ai fait 349 points à Nostramadus : La Dernière Prophétie !!! Alors ???????" (Note de moi-même : j'ai fait 349 points pour info). Je crois qu'ils ont voulu faire genre (et d'ailleurs c'est écrit dans les crédits à la fin) "hééé mais t'as fait x points, pas mal mais est-ce que tu pourras faire mieux ? ;))))" pour donner une sois-disant rejouabilité (lol). Autant le dire tout de suite : NON l'histoire ne changera pas si vous ne donnez pas de la confiture à la reine ou que vous vous chiez dessus sur une des énigmes. Donc, juste aucun intérêt de le refaire (à part le zizi tout dur, mais ça c'est votre problème).

Si vous aimez vous prendre la tête gentiment, vous déguiser en meuf/mec/moine (oui vous devenez un reverse trap) et faire du pain, CE JEU EST POUR VOUS.

Point bonus : ce jeu a été fait par un studio français donc jouez-y en français. En plus ça se passe en France. Donc immersion +++

review:

Única reclamação que eu tenho é que o jogo é relativamente curto, pois ele tinha bastante potencial para ser mais longo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052214710', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 147, 'playtime_forever': 49, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 49, 'last_played': 1398780975}
review:
This is an adventure game, pretty much like all others, but with some annoyances that makes it impossible to recommend it.

First, the settings. Which really aren't there... The game uses quite a low resolution, which cannot be changed at all. Low res on a 24" monitor, plus low fps (I'm guessing it's locked at 30 or so) - almost immediately after starting playing, it feels very straining on the eyes.

The game itself:

There hardly anything that explains how to play, and you'll have to mess around with the inventory a bit to understand how things works. That is, after you actually have found some items. Puzzles can be absolutely horrible, not because of the difficulty, but because of poor mechanics. For example, I was going to mix ingredients, did something wrong, and lost everything, with the result having to run around gathering them again.

The difficulty is mostly determined by how good you are at finding things, nothing else. If you overlook an item, a puzzle won't be solvable, and it's not easy to find them all. Nothing reveals what can be picked up, unless you point directly at it.

The game has voice acting - obviously they didn't hire professionals for it, because it's horrible.

Small changes could have made this one an excellent game, but as it currently is, I wouldn't recommend this game at all.

review:
Recommended with reservations - this is a decent game, but it didn't capture me, mainly because I'm not into astronomy and the pace is slow since I got stuck a lot.

I've only played the first day, so far, no hidden objects. There's a bit of recipe mashing, collecting ingredients and such, but for the most part, it is point & click. 

The graphics are 1024x768, and that looks decent enough (remember, TV and DVD have had worse resolution for decades). The graphic art is actually well done, I've seen a lot cheaper (and the orginal Myst never looked as good). That said, it is still a game where you stop at fixed positions, and then you can rotate the view and interact with the surroundings, or move to another position.

The game gets full marks for the atmosphere and the storyline so far; for the actual puzzling, there are too few hints, which had me needlessly stumped because I couldn't figure out what the game wanted me to do.

author: {'steamid': '76561198099216008', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 573, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 573, 'last_played': 1398542643}
review:
Here is another "old" game that I was very happy to be able to play after so long. I didn't remember most of it anyway.

What I truly love about this game is that most of the puzzles are very logical (and rather simple), unlike the new tendency of adventure games, which are usually based on gathering a lot random items without apparent reason, which you will have to combine (I positively hate pixel hunting), and where you don't always understand what you are supposed to do or, more important, why. In this game, everything you do has a purpose in the story. Futhermore, some of your choices have an impact on your progress (and score).

I liked the story and the artwork so much, that I didn't care that the quality of the graphics was not the last of the last. Oh, and I found a little bug that made me have to restart the game (the importance of saving).

Now, the truth is that it is a short game and the only interest of playing it again would be to try to get a higher score. But I am a sucker for this exact kind of game, so I loved it (and replayed it!).
